Description: Small mould-made scarab in Egyptian blue; back simply marked with single lines for main features and triangular nicks for humeral callosities; at side, legs not understood, represented by broad incised lines forming a triangle, but not cut away; underside incised with falcon holding a flail to right and half a cartouche to left, containing three debased hieroglyphic signs; longitudinally pierced; in Egyptian blue paste of bright colour and soft fine texture; much worn.
Curator's comments: This small scarab belongs to a standard group produced at the 'Scarab Factory' (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). It was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area, particularly in Italy and Punic sites and in south Russia (Gorton 1996, 109-111, type XXX, subtype A19-31, see especially A23 for this piece). The hieroglyphs in the "half cartouche", as seen in many similar examples, are often interpreted as a debased version of pharaohs' names, and, in that case, Gorton suggested the inscription could stand more precisely for Wa-ib-re, the Horus name of Pammetichus I or the name of Apries (Gorton 1996, 110). Variants of this type were discovered in Naukratis (Petrie 1886, pl. 37, no. 71-73). Similar motif on Paris, Louvre Museum E8056 bis.9 and Boston, Museum of Fine Arts 86.695. For another close parallel from Naukratis, where the falcon holding a flail is replaced by a winged griffin: Oxford, Ashmolean Museum AN1896-1908-EA.925. Gorton, A. F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W. M. F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, 'Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site', in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming, Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 72)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 110-111, Type XXX A23)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OE.29) (phase 3)
